title: How to stop failing in high school and turn my life around to get better grades - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve got this. Since young my grades have not been fantastic; I even have to drop subjects and also on the near edge of repeating my junior year in high school because of my grades. But gradually, I improved in my senior year. Subsequently in college, my grades are above average. The first thing to take note of is that, studying is a consistent effort. If you are constantly revising materials, then it will be easier to study when exams are coming. However, if you do not listen attentively in class and understand the content, then trying to squeeze all the knowledge into your brain in the last week before the test will be useless. Second, understanding is the most important thing. You need to understand the materials and not just purely memorize (but this also depends on the subject). For subjects that require more application skills, such as physics and math, then understand the logic behind them is important. For subjects that require some memory work, such as history, geography and biology, then put in consistent effort to revise them from time to time so that you are familiar with the concepts. Thirdly, you need motivation to study. I realize that my grades are bad not because I’m less intelligent than my peers, but because I am lazy in general and do not have the motivation to learn. The situation will be worse when you got bad grades, because you have no incentive to improve and the rewards of good grades are slow to come. Yet there’s a need to ask yourself what do you want to achieve at the end of the day? Then work from there. Coming to study methods: (a) Read-up on class materials before lessons, take notes in class, organize the notes after class for easy revision. (b) Be clear about the concepts and definitions. For memory work, familiarize and revise them day to day so that memorizing won’t be an issue when exams are near. For more complicated ones, practice more revision papers so that you will learn how to apply the concepts. (c) Get help from your peers, ask them to test you or try to explain the answers to them. (d) Approach teachers to help you identify what went wrong and areas that you can improve, especially after you’ve gotten back your test paper. Overall, this really takes consistent and deliberate effort. On my side, my attitude towards learning had a huge change and that’s why I’m able to improve quite a lot. Yet, I do think that not everyone is a “study material”, meaning no matter how much you study, you still can’t get the desired results. But this doesn’t stop those people from achieving, they tend to do very well in college courses which they have strong interest in. Therefore you can see if you are considered as this group of people who just couldn’t accommodate to the usual high school education curriculum.

I know what you mean. “You're so brilliant, why don't you do better at school?” “I always thought that with your intelligence you'd be on the Honor Roll. I guess I was wrong.” “Why don't you TRY at least?” I've heard everything. My parents and teachers considered me an overconfident, procrastinating waste of immense talent. I didn't feel I was wasting myself though- I felt I simply was not challenged appropriately. School was boring and pointless; my teachers idiots who simply read from the text book- I could teach myself everything they spent the year droning about, a day before the exam. How could I be expected to do well in assessments for subjects I found pedantic and unnecessary? Now that I'm a teacher, I see how I was failed by an unsatisfactory education system. I did extremely well in subjects where I felt inspired by the teacher, or the material. The rest? I didn't give a shit. If you feel unmotivated by your curriculum or the faculty, chances are you won't do well. But here's the catch- nobody cares that your school sucks. They won't ask you WHY you didn't do well in high school. So how do you do better? Motivate yourself: Find a way to like the subject. Connect to it. I hated chemistry until I started going to the lab.Find out what your teachers require: Understanding concepts means nothing if you can't translate your knowledge onto the paper (or screen). How must you structure your answers? How much research is required? When should you cite? Who should you cite? Ask for help.Take notes: Trust me, even with a photographic memory, a person forgets. Learning is not simply visual, it is kinesthetic and audio as well. Whatever you hear that is new to you, note it down. Whatever you did in class, should be in your notebook for later reference.Come prepared: Read a few chapters ahead, or find alternate sources of information. The more you know, the better impression you'll make. Which brings us to our last….Impress your teacher: I'm going to be honest; we tweak grades. I push my students into A territory if I feel they've worked hard most of the term. An exam is such an arbitrary way of judging a student's potential and seasoned teachers don't give numbers the same value as a student's year round effort. If we see you focused, we will help you get that grade.If your teachers call you brilliant even though you're failing, you must be a prodigy, and regardless of what people tell you, geniuses are taken seriously primarily if they do well in school. Work on yourself.

DO SOMETHING!!! Actually sit down with your teacher and ask for help taking notes. Actually participate in class. Actually do homework. See, potential is a word that people love to throw around, but in the grand scheme of things it really means nothing. No one is going to pay you for your potential (unless you are a professional athlete LOL). They are going to pay you for your production! So what are you actually producing right now? Failing grades is not production. You need to get some help organizing and your teachers are the first place to start with getting that help. Perhaps a well organized classmate might be an asset as well, but YOU need to be the one who takes ownership of your organizational challenges. Perhaps you have a learning disability? No fault of your own…but again, you need to be able to come up with some strategies for dealing with that. So I guess what I am trying to say is, you need to get some help. YOU need to get some help. That means you need to seek it out. It is not going to chase you down. It is not going to tackle you and make you do it. Go, and ask someone to help you (teacher, friend, guidance counselor, school psychologist) because it is not going to get better on its own.

Hey there buddy! Here are some study hacks I can think of… Attendance comes first. Do not miss classes or days at school unless it is absolutely necessary. There is information given in class that you cannot get later. Keep notes and handouts organized, and in order. When you are given a handout, put the date at the top so it stays in the right order in your binder. If you have to read and make notes on a chapter, do it right away, the same night. Don't let reading assignments pile up; in fact, don't put anything off. If you stay on top of it, you don't have to worry about going under. If you don't understand something or are struggling, get help right away. Don't give up until that teacher has helped you figure it out. The only stupid question is the one that isn't asked. I hate to say it, but teachers are human, and when they grade work their feelings about the student do come into play to a small degree. Do not grub for grades, make a pest of yourself, act up in class or do anything else that will lower your teacher's opinion of you. Review periodically throughout the term - you will be better prepared for exams. Start studying early for exams, and do not study the night before a test or the day of it. If you don't know it by then, you haven't done it right. Don't cram. Study in an area that has everything you need. There is no need to eliminate television, music, etc. unless it interferes with your concentration. Some students study better with a bit of activity around them, others need absolute quiet. Determine what works for you. Time management is critical. Set a time period to do homework and study that is consistent, and do not go beyond it. Say from 7 - 9 p.m. This is after dinner, and allows for you to watch a little tv, read, get ready for bed, and still get to sleep early. It is important to have a set schedule and stick to it, or your studies will run away with you and you'll get burned out. Let things go. If you're hung up on a 13/20, you're not focusing on getting a higher mark on the next thing. Don't belabor your work - if the essay is done, and it looks good, let it go, don't keep picking at it. Perfectionism and obsessiveness will do you in if you're not careful. That's about all I can think of, hope it helps, and have a good day!

Some how you have associated pain to studies. So you find it hard to focus when it comes to studies. Studying is also a pleasure, games is another pleasure, list is endless depends on the person. If you start associating pleasure to studying, you will choose to do it. When Pele(the football legend) received his first payment for a match that he played , he said “This is interesting. I am allowed to do what I love to do the most and also get paid for that” . He had associated pleasure to playing football.Download and watch inspirational videos. There are plenty available on YouTube. The most inspiring ones are the ones where they show how the most successful people once had the most bitter failures.Work hard, really hard. Luck favours the brave is a old paradigm. New paradigm is “The harder you practice , the luckier you get”. Believe in it.Don't talk or think about your depression. Talk more about what is good in your life. Your mind is like a magnet. It will attract things that you think or talk. The MOST SELFISH THING YOU CAN DO IS TO THINK AND TALK GOOD.Get your basics right. Hunt for knowledge. Try to think out of the box. Imagine, you will be wrong at times but you will gather the right facts.Disregard the people who put you down. Surround yourself with people who you think are creative and smart. It might make you look dumb at times but that's the price you pay to grow.Oh and did I tell you , you are not depressed. You are wonderful the way you are. Go on my friend. Whole world of possibilities awaiting for you. Make every day count. Have productive days ahead.

First of all stop the stress about grades. I had a 30+ year career in high tech and hired a lot of people and never once asked about anyone’s grades. And I don’ remember anyone ever asking about mine. Really not even ONCE. OK they matter when you are trying to get into some school maybe; when you have no work record maybe someone will care about them. But it’s not all that. It’s certainly NOT worth killing yourself over! Besides you will figure this out. If you are of average or better intelligence you will be able to get decent grades. Might be worth looking at whether you have learning disabilities but there other first steps. Talk to your teachers, talk to your school counselor. Tell them you feel you can do better but really don’t know to study effectively. Ask for help. Almost any teacher, every teacher, will want to help. If you don’t feel they are helpful tell your parents that you want to find a tutor or after school study program that can help you learn.

Don’t look at the wall - pick a brick. Deal with it one brick at at time. Appreciate small wins, expect set-backs and failures but realize to be good at anything takes practice. pick a brick. Smile. My tips for studying: Take handwritten notes Transcribe the notes to clean them up, reading them aloud as you do so. Highlight transcribed notes for key points. Can you explain it to a 4-year old? If not, you don’t understand it. Flashcards can help in certain subjects. A GOOD study buddy to quiz each other can be very useful too It’s really not as hard as you think once you get into your groove. Kicked out of college the first go around. Returned later - 4.0 GPADual Masters - 4.0 GPA YOU CAN DO IT! Just be honest with your self. What is stopping you from getting straight A’s? Address it! Take breaks. Stay positive. Have faith in yourself. There will be setbacks and disappointments. Learn from them. Set the course for the next challenge. Adopt, Adapt, Improve. Good luck

Go easy on yourself. Try whatever makes you feel better. Even if it's crying in a corner. Go back to studying after. Keep a check on what you've gotten done in a day. It's very important to make yourself feel guilty for not studying.See a psychologist. It's the best help you can find. Talk to friends, family, whoever is close and you think will at least listen. Don't keep building on the sucky feelings.Remember to make friends who are innately encouraging, don't compare yourself to anyone and don't do drugs. Have ambition and follow it!Simple things like writing out your daily goals and sticking it up on your wall are good ways to get work done.

First get rid of the negative thoughts. Grades won't decide how you will be. Try to be positive. Make good friends with one or with yourself. You don't need your entire class to be your friends. Greet everyone you know no matter what their reply is, with joy & smile. This will boost your social life. For learning quickly play sports /videogames. It also ends you with good friends. Learn for knowledge instead of grades. Try to understand topicwise instead of question to answer basis. . Don't quit the topic though it may take hours to finish. Take help from classmates and seniors or from Google all the time if you don't have real friends. Grades are just a number knowledge / experience only helps you in a long way. All the best.

Getting bad grades isn’t the end of the world and certainly isn’t worth killing yourself over. Many people drop out of high school and become successful. My own grades weren’t that great either. Also it depends upon your definition of bad grades as in some high schools even a D is considered passing. In any event, if you have bad grades there are several things you can do about it: ask the teacher for help, especially if you don’t understand something. Perhaps there is some extra homework you can do to practice more before testsstudy longer hours. If you are getting Cs when you study say 2 hours, then it makes sense that to get an A you would need to study a lot more, say 6 hours, provided you understand the material.get a tutor. This is probably the best idea because then you can get one on one help to understand the material.Even in a worst case scenario if you flunked out of high school, it isn’t the end of the world. For one thing, in the US you can get a GED at any age which is equivalent to a high school diploma. For another, not all jobs require a high school diploma.

You have accomplished the first step, identifying what doesn't work. At 17 you still have lots of opportunities to get it right. Life is not pass or fail. At Philmont, Boy Scout Ranch, there is a tradition at the end of a project or adventure to talk about roses, thorns and buds. Roses are things that worked. Thorns are problems. Buds are things that were done or experienced that show promise in the future. Java and computer science, at least the way you approach them are your thorns. Find your roses and pursue them. Identify your buds and determine what you need to do to make them bloom. Remember that no one else can do any of this for you. You may fail again. That doesn't mean that you stop or give up. It means that you need to honestly assess your situation and move forward with caution.

I also had this problem of not knowing ‘how’ to study. It was quite an adventure figuring it out. I find the best and only real way to study is to take the test.The best thing that happened to me was making a quizlet. You can put in terms/definitions, questions/answers etc and test yourself. My friends and I also used to study by making it like a game show, and whoever got the answer correct first got points. You’ll be surprised how much competition makes people remember. Lastly sometimes I listen to an audio version of whatever I need to remember while I’m sleeping. I don’t know if it actually works, but I feel like my subconscious will absorb the information, ahaha.

I had this one class, terrible teacher, first day and I got overwhelmed with how much work he tried to put on the class. Any speech I do, I write my passion with it. To resolve this issue it’s better to talk to your parents or true friends or meditate what motivated you to earn a higher grades before and think the future ahead of you. This simple stuff is simple but ignoring the roots and jump to the solution might be the wrong way to return your motivation in your studies. A simple step may worked for your concern.

Memorize stuff with a stop watch. If you do not have one readily available - use the stopwatch on your phone. Speed is your friend, so is repetition. Learning a language : Learn some useful words and sentences. Use them. With your parents. Learn by reading stuff You find interesting. Memorize words by covering the answers and writing Your answer - repeat Learning math : Understand the concept by trying the examples Practice applying it by doing exercises Eveything else : Take notes of what You find central Generally : Repeat everything You did for two days while adding a new portion of the same amount every day. I.e. every day You do three days of work, but only one third is new.

I heard the same thing when I was in high school. But now I work at a school and the teachers have shown me the current way to study, which I have relayed to you many times already. To get organized have a dedicated place to study. preferably at a desk. Gather up everything you will need and have it at your fingertips so it is readily available to you to just grab. Then actually do the reading, etc.

It sounds as though you are leading a self-fulfilling promise. You are wasting your life because your depression is getting in the way .  What happens then is that you are relying on your depression to keep you from studying. Actually depression is a natural phenomenon that is telling you that something is wrong. It isn’t the depression that’s needs to be fixed.  You need to change the reason that is getting you depressed.  Depression is caused by unfilled desires that have happened over time.  It can be more complex than what I am saying, but I am making basic statements as for you to look at the probable cause. The simple advice is to start studying; make it happen.  At some point, you just make yourself do it; do it for yourself…and then just continue on.

Sounds like you have something else consuming your time. Stop doing it and focus those hours on your studies. While in high school, one thing took up all my time, I served as dungeon master to my 2 younger brothers. We spent hours on the living room floor playing. Anybody remember, Judges Guild.

To answer this question, you should be an active student. This means take notes ( don’t just take notes without knowing the content, if possible paraphrase on what you learn class in your own words). Cornell Notes is a good note-taking skill. In addition, you should utilize websites such as Khan Academy or even a Youtube video if you are stuck on a particular topic. If it is something like math, make sure to get enough practice. It will help on your quiz and finals. Let say you are memorizing numerous words and phrases, there is an app called Anki (Anki - powerful, intelligent flashcards) that will help you remember certain things easier and better. Recap Take notes ( opt. Cornell notes) Don’t understand anything ( then go to Khan Academy or a Youtube video) Math- Practice Foreign Language, Science and others - Use Anki

When you have depression, it's hard to find motivation to do the things you need or want to do. Having depression is not a curse or a mistake, that's the first thing to realize. Depression can be overwhelming and very draining and that's okay. The best way to be productive while you have depression is to take small steps. You might just study for ten minutes but that's better than none. Slowly you can add another minute to those minutes. Also it helps to try and make studying fun if you watch interesting videos on the topic or have someone to motivate you. Other than that, meditation helps to refocus your mind. Good luck!

You need a study partner: someone who asks you questions, listens to your answers, and have you find the right answer when you miss the target. It’s obvious that you can’t pull this off alone at the moment. Another person can help you find out what mistakes you’re making in order to correct them.

To me it seems like 1 or 2 problems. 1) You might be trying to cram, study all this the day before. Studying days or even a week before would practice moving that info from short term memory to long term, so you can remember it for the test. 2) You might not be making a connection to the material. Brute memorization doesn’t give you an understanding. What helps me is I try to make the info fun and relate-able. The weirder/funnier you make the connection the better (remember Roy G BIV for teh visible colors in science?). And lastly as a tip, study the material ahead and then meet with a friend (one that gets this stuff) and explain the material to him. If you can explain it to someone, then you can explain it on a test. Plus, because he/she gets this, that person can correct you if you don’t get the material completely. Best of luck!
